I’m torn on this subject.

On the one hand, I’m definitely against lying to people. And that’s what this is, really: lying. There aren’t three states of matter, there aren’t five senses, etc.

But on the other hand, part of the challenge of teaching is breaking a complicated subject down into understandable packets that students can get. You don’t start teaching math to an elementary student by saying “not only are there positive numbers, but negative numbers as well. Also, some numbers are just straight up not perfectly representable. Also there are imaginary numbers. The set of numbers is infinite, but in some circumstances countably so.” You don’t teach a seven year old the axioms of set theory and the set of all real and imaginary numbers. You say “numbers are things we count. 1, 2, 3...,” and so on until they get that. Using their understanding of counting numbers, you can introduce zero, and negatives, and decimals, and irrationals, and so on. Knowledge is gained by expanding up knowledge that’s already BEEN gained, it’s recursive like that.

Similarly, saying things like “gravity is affected by mass” and “there are three states of matter” and “there are five senses” is, in my opinion, somewhat forgivable. No ten year old is gonna be able to understand special relativity, hell most adults can’t. If a child doesn’t even know what a gas is, how are they going to understand plasma? Or a Bose-Einstein Condensate? If a kid doesn’t understand that sight is a sense, how could they ever understand the vestibular sense, or proprioception? Energy isn’t really all that visible and concrete, but “big things are big” certainly is.

The basis of all knowledge comes from things we can observe. That’s why we HAVE to start small and concrete: counting numbers and base senses, solids/liquids/gas, etc. Once we’ve gained a base understanding of this, we can use that knowledge to assess something else. Then, once we’ve gained an understanding and acceptance of THAT, we can use it to gain more knowledge, etc. It builds upon itself.

Throwing someone who can’t swim into the deep end will drown them. Teaching someone that 2+2=4 under the condition that you’re working with base10 scalars in standard arithmetic will confuse them. Saying that gravity is actually a function of the speed of light and dependent on energy will frustrate them.

You'd never be able to teach anyone anything if you started out by explaining all the complexities; that's trying to run before you can crawl. Instead, you start with an overly simplified explanation that is true enough for the current moment. You talk about Newtonian physics, because it's an approximation that's good enough for almost anything a human will ever do. You talk about atoms like little solar systems because that's a good way to understand things like particle charge and energy states, and that's good enough to get the basics down before you go into the crazy stuff like electrons existing as a cloud of probability and bizarre electron orbital shapes.


Your "suppose" with the flat earth is the wrong way to see it; when we lie to children, we aren't teaching something that's completely and utterly wrong. Rather, we're teaching a simplified, less difficult version of the truth. It's approximately true. We say the earth is a sphere, when it really is a little bit squashed and also bumpy. We say the sheep is moving at 4 mph, because that's roughly true, and you need very sensitive instruments (and a very fast sheep) to detect that it isn't exactly true.


And that's how science works. We never come up with absolute truth. We always leave room to add another "except" later on, and that doesn't mean what we did before isn't true. It just means we're getting more and more refined in our understanding.

Now if you’re not quite sure what I’m getting at here is a simple experiment you can do. take a piece of string about 9 inches long. To people complaining that he approximated the speed of light: there is a difference between approximating the value of a physical constant and approximating a theory.  For example, the simple addition of velocities is an approximation to the more correct formula given in the video.  The two different ways to calculate the velocity represent two different physical laws; the approximation affects the underlying physics of the calculation. On the other hand, approximating the speed of light affects only the result of the calculation: the physics is the same whether you use the "true" value (which we don't really know since there's a limit to how accurately we can measure it) and the approximate value. It may be misleading to claim that an approximated theory is correct, but it is entirely inconsequential whether you give the exact or approximate value for a constant unless you are doing a calculation that requires an accurate answer.

We're not misleading ourselves and our nature about the true nature of things.

Science builds models to predict outcomes of events in the universe. As science gets better, we use better and better models - but every model, even special relativity - is just an approximation meant to give us an easy mathematical way to get a useful prediction out of a set of starting values.

We use basic newtonian physics to predict a lot of motion here on earth because it is a good enough approximation without putting in too much crunchy mathematics. We use lewis dot structures to predict certain chemical reactions because those predictions still work for a lot of the reactions we care about, we think of gravity as the attraction of masses because it works for the application of getting to the moon.

science gets better all the time, and we are constantly updating our models - but this doesn't mean the old models are useless for predicting the things they used to predict before, the new model just predicts all the old stuff PLUS a bunch of new stuff. it would be silly to ask middle school students to add velocities using (v1+v2)/((1-(v1+v2)/c^2) for everything - the difference would probably not even register on their calculators, and now you've gone and made everything harder for no reason. Also, when the model updates and we realize that we need to account for some different universal constant in that equation, then we're right back at the same problem - except now the students have been taught this new system as "Truth" instead of as "A good approximation".

The solution is to do what a lot of science teachers already do - explain to the students that the equations they're using are general case approximations given the average conditions on earth, and then get into specifics when the situation calls for it. Teach the fact that science doesn't make claims about truth, science only creates models (which get progressively better and better) that accurately predict phenomena observed in the universe.

I do think it's a good excuse to mislead our children (but not necessarily ourselves). While it goes without saying that we as a species should strive for the absolute truth, not just some approximation, I argue that it's ok we keep our children partially "in the dark" for one simple reason:

With our current education system (at least in the western world), every child is learning a little bit of everything right from the start. It is a good thing. The main purpose of school is not to teach hard facts about our universe and society but to "activate the brain", i.e. teach how to remember, how to think, how to reason. While teaching popular (simplified) physics to small children, we not only do that, we are also giving them the opportunity to falling in love with the field and pursuing advancement in the field even after school. Same goes for other school subjects.

Although a young person's brain is very fast-learning and can store great amounts of information relatively quickly, it just wouldn't work if we swamped it with detailed facts about every aspect of our lives and of our universe, right from the start. The child would find in unnecessarily challenging and become disinterested. Instead we are trying to ignite its intrinsic motivation with the subject, which of course is the best way to achieve anything, ultimately for the advancement of science through that person's specialized profession or research, as we hope.

While I get where your going with teaching false truths to people leading to common misconceptions, sometimes it's easier to grasp complex concepts when told with small mistruths. As you progress into further studying of those concepts those mistruths get revealed allowing you to more fully appreciate the actual complexity of the problem. If you try to start at the most complex state of the concept at its original introduction, many people will be immediately lost and will have a hard time grasping the actual concept.

Take metabolism as an example. We often teach students about the krebs cycle and multiple other regulatory pathways. Those are only at the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the crazy amount of complex chemical interactions that occur to make up metabolism. Not to mention all of the various hormonal pathways that alter it. If you presented metabolism with hundreds of various pathways (some of which aren't even known)... most students wouldn't have a clue as to what the hell they were looking at let alone what's actually important with the cycle.

So yes... most teaching systems have built in mistruths... but the point of that is to allow people to grasp difficult concepts without overloading their brain with information. Once they are able to grasp that big picture... you can add in complexity.

People also think that motion is just relative, and thus implying that there is no such a thing as absolute motion.

Imagine that we exist within a four dimensional environment. This environment is composed of three dimensions of space and one dimension of time. Call it, space-time. Now imagine that all objects that exist within this four dimensional space-time, are all constantly moving. Also a imagine that all of these objects are constantly moving at the speed of light.

OK. Now if an object in this four dimensional environment was at rest in space, its entire motion would be across the dimension of time, and it would be moving across the dimension of time at the speed of light. Or, if an object was moving across space at this speed of light, its motion across time, would have come to a complete standstill. Imagine also an object that was at rest in space, and thus it was moving across the dimension of time, and that this object extended across space to say a length of 5 feet, thus we would be observing a 5 foot length object.

However, if this object were to now change its direction of travel within 4D space-time, rotation would also occur. As a consequence of this, the 5 foot length of the object would no longer just be extending across space, now that it has rotated within the four dimensional structure known as space-time.

Thus, previous observers who had previously observed the 5 foot length object, would now see the object being of a shorter spatial length. If clocks were on board this object, they would also observed that these clocks are now ticking at a slower speed, and they do so since the motion of the object, and the clocks, is now partially across space, and thus its motion is no longer completely across the dimension of time only.

Anyhow, if you analyze the outcome of what happens if you have all objects all moving at the speed of light within a four dimensional space-time environment, you soon end up independently discovering special relativity, and you also independently derive all the special relativity equations.

Another misconception is that the speed of light is a slight misnomer. I say slight because it is in fact the limit on the speed of light. However, a more appropriate name would be the speed of information. Information cannot be transmitted at faster than the speed of light. This includes electric and magnetic information (i.e. light), but also gravity (and some other forces physicists are trying to figure out, like quantum linked particles).

A great example is if the sun ceased to exist instantaneously. Just like where it would take about 8.3 minutes before we stopped seeing the sun, it would also take about 8.3 minutes for us to no longer feel the gravity of the sun. And it would take 4 hours before Pluto no longer felt the gravity of the sun.

I think this video misses the mark a bit on the philosophy of science.  We aren't teaching children "the truth" of the world through science, we're teaching them some models to apply to the world for various applications.  We adapt our models depending on the application - a physicist might consider a sheep generally as a solid mass, whereas a biochemist might be concerned with individual proteins located in a particular part of the sheep.  Reasonable approximation is necessary in any model.
